comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: London Scottish, possibly. Kilt, badge and sporran all seem to match. That may be true for many regiments though.

wrt London Scottish: The 1st battalion served in Ireland between October 1919 and January 1920.
2nd battalion in 1921.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The swagger stick and the single epaulette bobble would presumably make him a subaltern - 2nd lieutenant, I guess.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
So, 2nd lieutenant in the 2nd batallion, London Scottish in 1921. How hard can that be? (Hint: the internet has no idea).

Our friend [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] is usually good for that sort of thing.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Young Carol, what has happened to your popularity over the recent past I see that some of your pictures now get over 30,000 views which seems to be miles ahead of even a few months back? care to comment?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] No problem at all, Danny! Not entirely clear on the detail and I'm not sure anyone is, but all down to changes in algorithms, etc. that Flickr use. People seeing your photo on the home page or in search results now counts as a view, I think. Also they used not include views on mobile devices (again I think), so those views used not be counted. To be honest, the number of views is not half so important to me as the number (and obviously quality - for which I thank you all heartily) of comments that we get...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I hear what you modestly say, but the number of *Favourites"  has jumped also (which is elective) not uncommon to see near 100 now as against an average of 30 or less a year ago.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] You're right, they have risen too! Will have to second you to do my monthly stats wrangling for my manager...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 51964676@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02]  He's a private- an officer would be wearing a jacket with an open neck, showing his collar and tie. What look like "pips" are brass shoulder titles.
Lots of ordinary soldiers bought swagger-sticks, you see a lot of photos of them carrying them- off duty of course.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/ajw423uk] Well, that opens up the field a bit. A battalion would still have been upwards of 300 in 1920, though presumably not the full thousand for territorials in peacetime just after a massive war.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: My money is on the London Scottish regiment, his cap badge looks very much like this one when you enlarge it. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Drumlondonscottish2.jpg . Would also make sense with the kilt and wool socks.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: If he's World War One-ish, here's the regiment list: 1914-1918.invisionzone.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=151369. More likely :In September 1919, the 1st Battalion again embarked for imperial service, taking up garrison duties in Rangoon, and in August 1920 the 2nd Battalion was sent to Ireland for service in what would later become the Anglo-Irish War; they would remain there until January 1922.[37] en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Scots

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: London Scots regiment, in for the Anglo-Irish War, gone by 1922. How's that?
